terms.definition: Managed Service Provider - a company that remotely manages a customer's IT infrastructure and end-user systems
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems
A web-hosted system that allows teams to create, store, and manage documentation accessible from anywhere with internet connection
Technical documents that describe IT systems, processes, configurations, and procedures for maintenance and troubleshooting
Software that is installed and run on the user's own servers rather than on a third-party cloud service
The combination of programming languages, frameworks, tools, and technologies used to build and run an application
Software as a Service - a software distribution model where applications are hosted by a service provider and accessed via the internet
Security measures that determine who can view, edit, or manage specific documents and resources within a system
The process of connecting different software applications through their APIs to enable data sharing and functionality
A system that tracks changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to revert to previous versions if needed
A collaborative website or platform that allows multiple users to create, edit, and organize content collectively
Software whose source code is freely available for anyone to view, modify, and distribute
The ability to track and manage IT systems, devices, and networks from a distant location using specialized software
The systematic tracking and management of IT equipment, software licenses, and digital resources throughout their lifecycle
A centralized web-based interface that provides organized access to various types of documentation and knowledge resources
